title.rendered: Find Rooms For Rent In Lincoln Park, Chicago

content.rendered:
Wondering where you can find lush greenery, comfortable living, and excellent public transport? You found it! Here’s why you should start looking for rooms for rent in Lincoln Park, Chicago!

Getting to know Lincoln Park, Chicago

Named after the famous Lincoln Park, this is a community area on the Northside of Chicago that many people move to every year. The area is filled with diverse architecture – from old Victorian buildings to modern condos for young professionals. It is also home to some architecturally significant churches, such as the St. Clements Church and St. Michael’s Church.

Apart from the famous park that was named after Abraham Lincoln, there other green spaces in the city such as the Lincoln Park Conservatory and Lincoln Park Zoo waiting to be explored.

Fun Fact: John Mulaney grew up in Lincoln Park!

Finding rooms for rent in Lincoln Park, Chicago

Find Rooms For Rent in Lincoln Park

The average rent in Lincoln Park is only slightly lower than the rest of Chicago. While you can find some cheap rooms for rent in Lincoln Park, some neighborhoods are more expensive than others, especially if you need to account for parking fees as well.

Elementary School in Lincoln Park

Lincoln Park is home to some top-rated schools, like Prescott Elementary School, Mayer Elementary School, and the Lincoln Elementary School. Excellent school districts, and the abundance of green spaces where kids can play, attract young families to this area.

A vibrant nightlife, numerous entertainment options, and prime shopping locations attract young professionals to Lincoln Park, making it a densely populated area in Chicago.

Related: Questions You Need To Ask Your Potential Roommate Before Saying Yes

Top neighborhoods near Lincoln Park, Chicago

  • West DePaul: West DePaul is an up-and-coming, affluent neighborhood where finding cheap rooms for rent can be a struggle. If you’re planning on finding rooms for rent in this Lincoln Park neighborhood, you may want to opt for living with a roommate.
  • Clybourn Corridor: Known as Northside’s primary shopping district, rent in this neighborhood can be much higher than the average rent in Lincoln Park. Convenient access to entertainment options makes it a coveted neighborhood among young professionals looking to have a fun night out at the end of a workday.
  • Old Town Triangle: Famous for its historic architecture, this neighborhood is filled with Victorian buildings, small cafes and quaint roads. For those looking for a suburban atmosphere, this is the best place to be!

Related: Finding Professional Growth In 2021

Average rent in Lincoln Park, Chicago

Related: Groceries And Roommates: How To Budget Better!

University life in Lincoln Park, Chicago

Lincoln Park is home to the famous DePaul University, known for excellence in academics and their sports team, the Blue Demon.

Students enjoy on-campus housing, with Freshmen and Sophomore students living in residential dorms, while Juniors and Seniors can opt for university-owned lofts, townhouses and apartments.

Students can look forward to Homecoming in the spring and FEST, which is an outdoor concert that takes place every year.

Related: Help! I Need Tips on How to Save Money in My 20s

University life in Lincoln Park, Chicago

Lincoln Park is home to the famous DePaul University, known for excellence in academics and their sports team, the Blue Demon.

Students enjoy on-campus housing, with Freshmen and Sophomore students living in residential dorms, while Juniors and Seniors can opt for university-owned lofts, townhouses and apartments.

Students can look forward to Homecoming in the spring and FEST, which is an outdoor concert that takes place every year.

Related: Help! I Need Tips on How to Save Money in My 20s!

How transit-friendly is Lincoln Park, Chicago?

Thanks to Chicago’s excellent public transit system, Lincoln Park residents don’t need to own a car to get around the city easily. From buses and rail lines to taxis and rideshare services, residents have several transport options to choose from. If you prefer driving, be sure to keep up with the news to avoid busy areas during rush hour.

Walkability

With a walk score of 94, Lincoln Park is extremely walkable and among the top ten most walkable neighborhoods in Chicago. You can complete most errands on foot, making it easier for you to get your daily steps in!

Roads/traffic

Traffic conditions are not as good as they could be, and it’s hard to get away from congestion on the roads, especially during rush hours. The typical commute time for Lincoln Park residents is around 30-34 minutes. Lake Shore Drive and Diversey are known to be dangerous for runners and pedestrians – so take extra care if you’re on foot in these areas.

If you’re in a rush, check the local news station as they provide constant updates on traffic around intersections and which areas to avoid.

For those who love to travel by car, keeping the scarcity of parking spaces in mind is crucial. You’ll be hard-pressed to find an open parking space, especially near older neighborhoods and waterfront areas.

Taxis in Lincoln Park

Numerous taxi services, car rentals, and rideshare services such as Uber and Lyft are available in Lincoln Park. When you want to avoid the hassle of public transit, you can opt for either of these options.

Public transportation

For residents without a car, public transit is conveniently accessible across the city. You can take the local bus or train to explore the city at your convenience. In Lincoln Park, you have access to the three CTA Lines – the Red, Brown, and Purple Line. Several bus routes are present across the city, which can be conveniently accessed by residents and tourists alike. The Chicago Transit Authority’s official website provides more information regarding routes, fares, and schedules.

Airports

The closest airport to Lincoln Park is the Chicago Midway International Airport, which is just 10.8 miles away, followed by Chicago O’Hare International Airport, which is 13.8 miles away. For convenient and affordable transport, opt for airport shuttles or any other public transit.

Cycling

Lincoln Park is a haven for cyclists, with plenty of beautiful scenery to explore. Cyclists can view a bike map of the city, to see which areas offer a safe biking route. BikeLNK, launched in 2018, offers over 21 bike share stations in Lincoln Park and operates 24 hours a day.

Additionally, there are plans to introduce a “Greenway” biking lane which would run from Dickens Avenue to Lincoln Park Zoo, making biking more accessible to residents.

Restaurants in Lincoln Park, Chicago

If you’re a foodie (and who isn’t?), you’ll love exploring the city’s famous restaurants and eateries. The German and Irish heritage of the immigrants from the 1870s still has a strong influence on the food scene in Lincoln Park, allowing you to try diverse cuisines. From Michelin starred restaurants, to the farmer’s market, food finds a new meaning here!

  • Boka
  • Alinea
  • Twin Anchor’s Restaurant and Tavern

Nightlife in Lincoln Park, Chicago

While it may seem like a cookie-cutter neighborhood from the outside, Lincoln Park has a vibrant nightlife that you should not miss out on. It’s not just about rooftop bars and low-key dives, but you will find live music, theatre shows, and more. Don’t forget to have a night out with your friends once you get here – you’ll find some unforgettable spots!

  • Lincoln Hall
  • L.U.E.S
  • Steppenwolf

D’you know what else Roomi does outside of helping its readers find rooms for rent in Lincoln Park, Chicago? With our ever-increasing lists of rooms and roommates across the world, we help you find your perfect match! Download the app here and hop on the easiest ride home, ever!
